channel.title: NYT > Science
channel.copyright: Copyright 2026 The New York Times Company

item.title: Investigators Blame NASA and Boeing for Starliner Failures
item.description: Technical and oversight problems left two astronauts aboard the International Space Station for months longer than had been expected.
item.dc:creator: Kenneth Chang
item.media:description: The Boeing Starliner spacecraft that carried the astronauts Butch Wilmore and Suni Williams to the International Space Station, seen on July 3, 2024.

item.title: On an Ambitious Antarctic Quest, One Nation Is on the Sidelines
item.description: None of the main research on the voyage of the Araon was funded by the U.S. National Science Foundation, a sign of the difficult times for American science.
item.dc:creator: Raymond Zhong
item.media:credit: Chang W. Lee/The New York Times

item.title: A Lonely Baby Monkey Wins Hearts, and Even a Few Friends
item.description: Legions of fans from around the world have been cheering on Punch, a 7-month-old macaque who had been struggling to socialize at a zoo outside Tokyo.
item.dc:creator: Remy Tumin
item.media:credit: Ko Sasaki for The New York Times
item.media:description: Punch with his plush companion at Ichikawa City Zoo.

item.title: A Rare Glimpse of a Sleeper Shark in Antarctic Waters
item.description: Researchers filmed a 10-to-13-foot sleeper shark off the South Shetland Islands, in what may be the first recording of the species that far south.
item.dc:creator: Jenny Gross

item.title: Lake Erie’s Storm Surges Become More Extreme
item.description: Officials are designing new ways to protect the shorelines from sudden flooding and longer storm seasons.
item.dc:creator: Jim Robbins
item.media:description: Ice mounds along the shoreline of Lake Erie on Feb. 4, in Hamburg, N.Y.

item.title: E.P.A. Faces First Lawsuit Over Its Killing of Major Climate Rule
item.description: Environmental and health groups sued the E.P.A. over its elimination of the endangerment finding. The matter is likely to end up before the Supreme Court.
item.dc:creator: Karen Zraick
item.media:description: The E.P.A. last week erased the scientific finding that gave it the authority to regulate greenhouse gases. Cars are a top emitter of the gases, which cause climate change.

item.title: Documenting a ‘Drastically Changing’ Scientific Landscape
item.description: In the Lost Science series, scientists whose jobs or funding have been cut by the Trump administration tell their stories.
item.dc:creator: John Otis
item.media:credit: Andri Tambunan for The New York Times

item.title: Could an Electronic Coach Help Ski Jumpers Leap Farther?
item.description: Future Olympic prospects are testing a device that can give them corrective advice in real time as they hurtle into the air.
item.dc:creator: Eric Niiler
item.media:credit: Chang W. Lee/The New York Times

item.title: These Unsinkable Tubes Could Help Harvest Energy From the Ocean
item.description: Researchers developed aluminum structures that trap air bubbles, making them able to float perpetually in even the harshest environments.
item.dc:creator: Kenneth Chang

item.title: Data Centers and Your Power Bill
item.description: New A.I. sites could drive up your power bill. We look at possible solutions.
item.dc:creator: Claire Brown
item.media:description: An Amazon Web Services data center, foreground, under construction next to the Susquehanna nuclear power plant in Berwick, Pa., in 2024.

item.title: U.S. Tells International Energy Agency to Drop Its Focus on Climate Change
item.description: The Trump administration is threatening to leave the influential agency unless it stops publishing its annual road map for cutting planet-warming emissions.
item.dc:creator: Brad Plumer
item.media:description: Chris Wright, the energy secretary, during a visit to Venezuela this month.

item.title: An Antarctic Expedition Ends in New Zealand
item.description: But stay tuned: We’ve still got more to share about this Antarctic expedition, and the next ones scientists are already planning.
item.dc:creator: Raymond Zhong
item.media:credit: Chang W. Lee/The New York Times
item.media:description: The New Zealand coast seen from the icebreaker Araon as it neared the end of its journey on Thursday.

item.title: E.P.A. Plans to Loosen Mercury Rules for Coal Plants, Documents Show
item.description: Senior officials at the Environmental Protection Agency are expected to announce the move on Friday, according to people briefed on the matter.
item.dc:creator: Lisa Friedman and Maxine Joselow
item.media:credit: Alyssa Schukar for The New York Times
item.media:description: Coal plants are responsible for nearly half of all mercury emissions in the United States, according to the E.P.A.

item.title: N.I.H. Director Will Temporarily Run C.D.C. in Leadership Shake-Up
item.description: Dr. Jay Bhattacharya will serve as the acting director of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention until President Trump appoints a permanent director.
item.dc:creator: Sheryl Gay Stolberg
item.category: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
item.media:description: Dr. Jay Bhattacharya, the director of the National Institutes of Health, will serve as the acting director of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.

item.title: How Microbes Got Their Crawl
item.description: In the oceans and on land, scientists are discovering rare, transitional organisms that bridge the gap between Earth’s simplest cells and today’s complex ones.
item.dc:creator: Carl Zimmer

item.title: F.D.A. Reverses Decision and Agrees to Review Moderna’s Flu Vaccine
item.description: Moderna held further discussions with regulators and announced that the agency would accept the company’s application for approval of its flu vaccine that uses mRNA technology.
item.dc:creator: Christina Jewett and Rebecca Robbins
item.media:credit: Ryan Remiorz/The Canadian Press, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Moderna’s vaccine production facility in Laval, Quebec.

item.title: Cleaning Up Carnival, Bead by Plantable Bead
item.description: Mardi Gras in New Orleans can generate more than 1,000 tons of trash every year. A coalition of nonprofit groups, city officials and scientists has a plan to clean it up.
item.dc:creator: Jackie Delamatre

item.title: Vaccine Makers Curtail Research and Cut Jobs
item.description: Federal policies under Robert F. Kennedy Jr. that are hostile to vaccines have “sent a chill through the entire industry,” one scientist said.
item.dc:creator: Rebecca Robbins
item.media:description: Moderna says it plans to pull back on late-stage studies of some of its experimental vaccines.

item.title: Should Drug Companies Be Advertising to Consumers?
item.description: Aging means “becoming a target” of the industry, one expert said. After decades of debate, politicians of all stripes are proposing bans.
item.dc:creator: Paula Span

item.title: Alfred Blumstein, Who Transformed the Study of Crime, Dies at 95
item.description: An engineer by training, he used systems theory and quantitative analysis to examine criminal behavior, revealing the systemic patterns of crime.
item.dc:creator: Michael S. Rosenwald

item.title: Constant Sexual Aggression Drives Female Tortoises to Walk Off Cliffs
item.description: On a remote island in North Macedonia, male Hermann’s tortoises outnumber females 19 to 1, an imbalance driving the population to extinction.
item.dc:creator: Elizabeth Preston

item.title: Trump Erased the Endangerment Finding. Here Come the Lawsuits.
item.description: The battle is expected to reach the Supreme Court, which is far more conservative today than it was when the measure was established.
item.dc:creator: Karen Zraick
item.media:credit: Tierney L. Cross/The New York Times
item.media:description: President Trump announced on Thursday that his administration would scrap the endangerment finding.

item.title: A Climate Supercomputer Is Getting New Bosses. It’s Not Clear Who.
item.description: The National Science Foundation said management of the machine, used by researchers for forecasts, disaster warnings and pure science, would be transferred to a “third-party operator.”
item.dc:creator: Eric Niiler
item.media:credit: Caine Delacy for The New York Times
item.media:description: The supercomputer is currently run from the National Center for Atmospheric Research headquarters in Boulder, Colo.

item.title: Elephant Bone in Spain May Be Proof of Hannibal’s Tanks With Trunks
item.description: Archaeologists say a 2,200-year-old specimen is the first direct evidence of how the Carthaginian war machine used the giant mammals in the Punic Wars.
item.dc:creator: Franz Lidz
item.media:description: A Renaissance-era fresco attributed to Jacopo Ripanda depicting Hannibal on the back of an elephant during the Second Punic War, in the third century B.C.

item.title: RFK Jr. Allies Target States to Overturn Vaccine Mandates for Schools
item.description: Proponents of vaccines warn that the efforts will further dismantle the immunization infrastructure and lead to more outbreaks of disease.
item.dc:creator: Christina Jewett
item.media:description: An empty classroom at the high school in Williston, N.D., during an outbreak of measles there last year.
